content:
I apologize if my previous response was unclear. I did not mean to suggest that Pyrrhos would necessarily be against the gods, but rather that if he were to survive until the final battle in his world, he might see it as a test of his faith and an opportunity to fight for his beliefs.

Many religious and mythological traditions depict a final battle between the forces of good and evil, and individuals who are devout or committed to a particular faith may see such a battle as an important moment in their spiritual journey. In this sense, Pyrrhos might view the Armageddon in his world as a chance to prove his devotion to his gods or to fight for what he believes is right.

Of course, the specifics of Pyrrhos's beliefs and motivations would depend on the mythology and culture of his world, and it's impossible to say for sure how he would respond to such a scenario without knowing more about him and his world.
